layer_depth: This function can be used to change the depth of the given layer, changing the order in which its contents will be rendered to the screen. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and then give the new depth to set it to (an integer value form -16000 to 16000). The layer depth is defined as being higher when "further away" from the camera and lower when "closer" to the camera, so if you have three layers with depths -100, 0, 100, the layers will draw in the order 100, 0, -100, so that the "top" layer (ie, the closest to the camera view and so drawn over everything else) will be the layer with the -100 depth.

Note that you can check the depth of a layer at any time using the function layer_get_depth(). Also note that the minimum and maximum layer depths are -16000 to 16000, and anything outside of those depths will not be rendered. If you require a depth outside of that range then you will need to use the function layer_force_draw_depth().
